_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Zeco Inc. is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by

prioritizing environmental health and safety within its daily operations. The commitments are

documented in the company safety policies and procedures. Zeco management stresses

safe operations in employee training programs which include refresher training and updates to 

any changes made in Zeco's operations manual, and any changes made in the industry.



Description of Process

Zeco Inc. stores sanitation, soaps and intervention chemicals used in the food safety industry.

These chemicals are used throughout the industry for many different applications such as general 

cleaning of equipment and bacterial intervention. Intervention involves the use of Peracetic acid 

applied to protein carcass to eliminate bacteria and other pathogens that could potentially cause harm to the public.



Peracetic acid is delivered by tractor-trailer in individual vented IBC totes and L99 HMWPE Resin drums to the Cummings 

Road warehouse. Product is off loaded by forklift and stored in an isolated part of the warehouse in an separate internal building, away from the main tote 

and drum storage areas, that are awaiting purchase, pickup and delivery.  The enclosed PAA storage area is climate controlled and 

monitored by both PAA sensors and a fire protection system. 

The process is a basic inbound delivery with staging of the product and then re-loading for outbound deliveries to the customer.



Zeco uses trained fork lift operators to move the product throughout the process. The product

containers are not opened for any reason. Zeco employees do participate in emergency response actions and have been trained to do so. 

Zeco has spill kits available at all times and all employees go through class room training, followed by a spill demonstration. 

Zeco installed new technology,called a Steri-trac system for monitoring the PPM in the air to alert employees of a p

otential leak. 

In the event a spill should occur, the shipping employees are trained to stop a small leak of 10 gallons.

In the event of a large uncontrolled release of a tote, employees are instructed to evacuate and

cover the storm drains to prevent any release from outside the property of occurring. Also, the

employees will notify the local fire department and call Safety Kleen to aid with the spill clean-up.







Worst Case Scenario

An accidental release of the total amount of Peracetic Acid stored is believed to be unlikely due to the individual 

isolated storage methods used. Potential total release would be in the event ofnatural disaster, fire, or structural collapse. 

The calculated endpoint is .6 miles with public receptors within the distance to the endpoint. The facility contains a 24 hour 

monitored fire alarm system in which the Chattanooga Tennessee Fire Department would respond in case of emergency.



Alternative Release

Potential release of Peracetic Acid is determined to be by fork truck operator error by means of

puncturing the product container with the forks. Estimation of the forks entering

the lowest point of the container, with a release rate of 368 lbs./min at release duration of 5 minutes was calculated. In the event of such release, all employees are instructed on how to contain such leak and call Safety Kleen to provide support if needed. The local fire department will also be

contacted.



Maintenance

Pre-shift inspections are performed by the fork truck operator. Any deficiency is noted and put on schedule for repair. If any deficiency is found to compromise the safe operation of the unit, the unit is placed out of service and scheduled for repair. It is not permissible to alter or disable any safety feature placed on the unit by the manufacturer. Material KENCO of Chattanooga TN is contracted to perform maintenance and repairs on the fork trucks keeping the units safe to operate.  SteriTrack monitoring system sensors a

re replaced every four months.



Training

Required annual safety training is performed in coordination of current written safety programs.

Written safety programs and policies were updated in 2017 to reflect changes in requirements and best practices in the industry. All employees are required to undergo general safety training and function specific training prior to beginning the job. Management is always open to and seeking new techniques and methods to improve the overall safety, and reducing any environmental impact of our process.
